topics.title: Introduction and Background
topics.summary: Lenny introduces a compilation episode focused on learning from failure, why it’s valuable, and invites listener feedback.

topics.title: Sponsor Break
topics.summary: Sponsor messages for Sendbird (in-app communications API) and Eppo (A/B testing and feature management platform).

topics.title: Airbnb design team rebellion and trust
topics.summary: Katie Dill recounts early days at Airbnb when half the design team confronted her with written feedback; she learns the core issue was unearned trust and shifts to listening and bringing people along.

topics.title: Freezing on stage and recovering
topics.summary: Paul Adams describes freezing during a high-stakes Cannes keynote, walking off stage while still mic’d, then returning to finish—highlighting resilience and perspective after public failure.

topics.title: Google social product failures and fear-driven strategy
topics.summary: Paul reflects on Google Buzz/Google+ as fear-motivated efforts that led to privacy issues and poor outcomes, contrasting with Google’s other successes and emphasizing building from user needs.

topics.title: Embracing failure through shipping and learning
topics.summary: Paul explains Intercom’s culture of big bets and “ship fast, ship early, ship often,” and the ongoing tension between speed/learning and high craft standards.

topics.title: Pets.com: overfunding, arms races, and timing
topics.summary: Tom Conrad shares lessons from Pets.com: excess capital can drive irrational competition, timing matters (dial-up era constraints), and the team chose to shut down early and return remaining funds.

topics.title: Quibi: rekindled passion and broken business math
topics.summary: Tom describes joining Quibi reluctantly, loving the build, but learning that even strong execution can’t fix a fundamentally broken investment/returns equation—made worse by COVID disrupting content production.

topics.title: Fail conclusively: designing experiments to learn
topics.summary: Sri Batchu argues failure is fine if it produces learning; to avoid repeating inconclusive tests, design experiments with strong treatment effects (especially in B2B with small sample sizes).

topics.title: Airbnb Plus: solution-first thinking and unit economics
topics.summary: JZ explains Airbnb Plus as a major miss driven by jumping to an operationally heavy solution (inspections) instead of addressing the real trust/representation problem, and warns against “magical thinking” on unit economics.

topics.title: Career A-side vs B-side and hidden setbacks
topics.summary: Gina Gotthilf introduces the idea that people share highlight reels (A-side) while hiding struggles (B-side), then shares personal setbacks—dropping out, visa issues, layoffs/firings—and the importance of storytelling and perceived value.
